value.name: Umayyad Caliphate - Wikipedia
value.snippet: The Umayyad Caliphate or Umayyad Dynasty (661–750 CE) was the second caliphate established after the death of the Islamic prophet Muhammad. The caliphate was ruled by the Umayyad dynasty ( Arabic : ٱلْأُمَوِيُّون , al-ʾUmawīyūn , or بَنُو أُمَيَّة , Banū ʾUmayya , "Sons of Umayya ").

value.name: Umayyade-kalifatet - Wikipedia, den frie encyklopædi
value.snippet: Spredningen af islaminden for kalifatet gik dog langsomt, hvilket bl.a. skyldtes, at de arabiske erobrere almindeligvis ikke omgikkes lokalbefolkning, men boede i nyetablerede byer. I de områder, der i dag er Israel, Egypten, Jordanog Syrien, gik det langsomst, og der er fortsat kristne minoriteter.

value.name: What Was the Umayyad Caliphate - ThoughtCo
value.snippet: The Umayyad Caliphate was the second of four Islamic caliphates and was founded in Arabia after the Prophet Muhammad's death. The Umayyads ruled the Islamic world from 661 to 750 C.E. Their capital was in the city of Damascus; the founder of the caliphate, Muawiya ibn Abi Sufyan, had long been the governor of Syria .

value.name: Umayyad Caliphate - WorldAtlas
value.snippet: The Umayyad Caliphate was an Islamic Empire that ruled North Africa, the Middle East, and even significant parts of Europe and the Indian Subcontinent for nearly a century, between 661 CE and 750 CE. It was named for its ruling family, the Ummayads, who were named after their common ancestor, Umayya ibn Abd Shams, a member of the ...

value.name: The Umayyad Caliphate | Islamic History
value.snippet: The Umayyad caliphate was marked both by territorial expansion and by the administrative and cultural problems that such expansion created. Despite some notable exceptions, the Umayyads tended to favor the rights of the old Arab families, and in particular their own, over those of newly converted Muslims (mawali).

value.name: Umayyad dynasty | Achievements, Capital, & Facts | Britannica
value.snippet: Umayyad dynasty, also spelled Omayyad, the first great Muslim dynasty to rule the empire of the caliphate (661–750 ce), sometimes referred to as the Arab kingdom (reflecting traditional Muslim disapproval of the secular nature of the Umayyad state).

value.name: Umayyad Caliphate: Timeline & Achievement | StudySmarter
value.snippet: The Umayyad Caliphate ruled the Islamic world from 661 C.E. to 750 C.E. The founder of the Umayyad Caliphate was Caliph Muawiya. He chose the name Umayyad for his dynasty because Umayyad was a common ancestor that he and the Prophet Muhammad shared.

value.name: The Umayyad Caliphate: The Largest Islamic State
value.snippet: The Umayyad Caliphate: The Largest Islamic State. A few decades after the death of the Prophet Mohammed, the Islamic World produced its first great empire: the Umayyad Caliphate. In the years following Mohammed’s death, the Islamic Nation was ruled by four “rightly-guided” Caliphs.

value.name: The Umayyad Caliphate
value.snippet: The Umayyad Caliphate All dynasties Year 661-749 When Ali, the fourth caliph and last Islamic religious and political leader with close personal ties to the prophet Muhammad, died in 661, the Arab governor in Syria seized power. Muawiya came from the Umayya clan in Mecca and founded the first hereditary Islamic dynasty, the Umayyads.
